did.unittitle: Harry Stevens Papers, 1960s-1980s Gift through Herman H. Goldstine. (Ms Coll 99)
did.abstract: Photocopies of secondary and primary materials relating to Shawnee history and culture.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Primarily research material on the Shawnee Indian, including biographical information on Tecumseh, Teskwatawa, Cornstalk, and Black Hoof. Also, geographical information, by state, of the four Shawnee groups Absentee, Eastern, Caddo, and Cherokee with topical information on the economy, society, religion and vocabulary of the tribe.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Native American Images note : 642 black and white photocopies, with a few black and white silver gelatin photographs, negatives, and newspaper clippings of images of Shawnee chiefs and settlements copied from 1980-1982. Collected by Stevens for historical research, the images are from various archival source materials and published works. Of interest, photocopies of photographs by Jim Lynch of a 1936 Shawnee settlement in Sperry, Oklahoma. Many portraits of Tecumseh, Tenskwatawa, Black Hoof, and Cornstalk.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Harry Robert Stevens (1914- ) received his PhD in history from the University of Chicago in 1946. During his career he was an assistant, associate and full professor of United States history at the University of Cincinnati, Michigan State University, and Duke University, respectively. In 1976, he became an emeritus professor at Ohio University. His specialty is nineteenth century political, intellectual and frontier America. Many of his published scholarly articles appear in the Bulletin of the Historical and Philosophical Society of Ohio and the Ohio Archaeological and Historical Quarterly. Other published works include A Study of Notable Ohioans (1937), Six twenty: Margaretta Hunt and the Baker-Hunt foundation (1942), Early Jackson Party in Ohio (1957).
